definition: dagger-axe/abbr. for 戈瑞[ge1 rui4]/(Tw) abbr. for 戈雷[ge1 lei2]
to go to war (idiom)/to make a big fuss over sth
lit. to exchange weapons of war for gifts of jade and silk (idiom)/fig. to turn hostility into friendship
pinyin: hua4 gan1 ge1 wei2 yu4 bo2

sentences.english: The peace talks broke down completely, and the two opposing parties took up arms again.
sentences.chinese: 和平會談徹底破裂，對立雙方再起干戈。

sentences.english: Russia also has a strong political incentive to go easy on Ukraine.
sentences.chinese: 俄羅斯有強烈的政治理由與烏方化干戈爲玉帛。

sentences.english: Where were their armour and their arms?
sentences.chinese: 他們的甲冑和干戈藏在哪裏呢？

sentences.english: I was really proud of myself to escape a possible conflict.
sentences.chinese: 能夠避開一場可能的干戈，我真替自己感到驕傲。

sentences.english: Page 48: The clatter of armor and clanking of metal could be heard.
sentences.chinese: 鎧甲的嘩啦聲和干戈相碰的金屬聲已經能聽到。

sentences.english: This doesn’t necessarily have to involve full-on, life changing, epic events.
sentences.chinese: 這並不一定是要你大動干戈地全面改變自己的生活。

definition: fire beacon (used as alarm signal over long distance)
people are in a terrible situation (idiom)
old variant of 愷|恺[kai3]/old variant of 凱|凯[kai3]
the common people in a miserable state
to convert an enemy into a friend (idiom)
